title: 110_s1276
content: The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 clarifies signature capture and retention for electronic methamphetamine precursor logbook systems under the Controlled Substances Act. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 requires individuals to present an identification card issued by the State or Federal Government, sign a written logbook with their name, address, and the date and time of the sale for transactions involving methamphetamine precursors. The purchaser must provide a signature using a device presented by the seller for transactions involving an electronic logbook, linking the signature to other logbook information. The purchaser must provide a signature in an electronically-captured logbook, linking it to other information such as product details, quantity, purchaser's name and address, and sale date and time. The purchaser must sign a unique identifier linked to electronic information or written into the book by the seller at the time of sale. The bound paper book should display a specific notice. The purchaser must sign a printed document at the time of sale, containing product details, purchaser information, and a signature line. The document must display a specific notice. After the purchaser signs the document, it should be securely stored in a binder or other means of document storage. The seller records product name and quantity sold in a logbook, which can be done electronically. The logbook also includes purchaser's name, address, date, and time of sale. When entering information in the logbook, the seller must verify the purchaser's name and the accuracy of the date and time. If the seller inputs the information, the purchaser needs to confirm its correctness. Electronic methods like bar code readers can capture this information. The logbook must include a notice to purchasers about the consequences of providing false information, which may result in criminal penalties under section 1001 of title 18, United States Code. Sellers must maintain each logbook entry, whether written or electronic, for a minimum of 2 years.
